DIALOGUE: These hills are full of Apaches! They've burned every ranch in sight.
He had a brush with them last night. Says they're being stirred up by Geronimo.
Geronimo?
How do we know...
...he's not lying?
He's a Cheyenne. They hate Apaches worse than we do.
Clear the wire to Lordsburg.
That's Lordsburg calling. They seem to have something urgent for you, sir.
Well?
What's wrong?
Line's gone dead, sir.
What did you get?
Only the first word, sir.
'Geronimo'.
H'ya, Buck!... Howdy, Buck!... How's things in Bisbee, Buck? Have a good trip?
So long, Buck.
Howdy, Buck. Got that payroll for the mining company?
She's right here in this box.
Give us a hand with this box, Jim.
Jim, I'll pay you that $2.50 when I get through.
Okay.
Now you kids, get away from them wheels!
Well... sir, we ran into a little snow up there, quite bad, so you fellers better prepare for a good frost.
Passengers out for Tonto...
You folks might as well stretch your legs...
...your limbs, ma'am. We're changin' horses here.
Is there some place where I can have a cup of tea?
Well, ma'am, you can get a cup o' coffee right there in the hotel.
Thank you, driver.
You ain't looking very pert, ma'am.
I'll be all right, thank you.
Yes, ma'am.
Why, Lucy Mallory!
Nancy! How are you, Captain Whitney?
What are you doing in Arizona?
I'm joining Richard in Lordsburg. He's there with his troops.
He's a lot nearer than that, Mrs. Mallory. He's been ordered to Dry Fork.
That's the next stop for the stagecoach. You'll be with your husband in a few hours.
I'm so glad to see you, Lucy. Sit down with us and have a cup of coffee. You must be tired from that long trip.
Who is that gentleman?
Hardly a gentleman, Mrs. Mallory.
I should think not. He's a notorious gambler.
Hello, Mick. Howdy, Frank. Well, Marshal, I'm looking for my Shotgun Guard. Is he here?
Out with a posse, Buck... tryin' to ketch the Ringo Kid.
Ringo! I thought Ringo was in the pen.
He was.
Busted out? Well, good for him.
It's my guess the Kid's aimin' to get even with them Plummer boys.
Yeah, it was their testimony sent him to the penitentiary.
All I can say is he better keep away from that Luke Plummer. Gosh, Luke's run every friend o' Ringo's out of Lordsburg.
Last trip there I seen him hit a rancher with his gun barrel an' lay his head open like a butchered steer.
You seen Luke Plummer? In Lordsburg?
Yes sirree.
You boys take care of the office for a coupla days.
I'm goin' to Lordsburg with Buck. Goin' to ride shotgun.
Oh lor', Marshal, when am I going to learn to keep my big mouth shut...
Payroll, Mister Gatewood.
You know, ever since I opened this bank, I've been trying to tell those people to deposit their payrolls here six months in advance. It's good, sound business.
It's good business for you, Mr. Gatewood.
Here's your receipt. Fifty thousand dollars.
And remember this -- what's good business for the banks is good for the country.
Now, my dear lady...
Don't you 'dear lady' me, you old deadbeat! I'm keeping your trunk because you ain't paid your rent.
'Is this the face that launched a thousand ships...'
'...And burned the topless towers of Ilium?'
'Farewell, fair Helen.'
Doc! Doc!...
Doc! Can they make me leave town? When I don't want to go? Do I have to go?
Now, Dallas, don't go makin' no fuss.
Do I have to go, Doc? Just because they say so?
Now, Dallas, I got my orders. Don't blame these ladies. It ain't them.
It is them! What have I done, Doc? Haven't I any right to live?
We have been struck down by a foul disease called social prejudice, my child. These dear ladies...
...of the Law and Order League are scouring out the dregs of the town.
Come, be a proud, glorified dreg like me.
You shut up, Doc. You're drunk.
I'm glorified, sir.
Two of a kind.
Just two of a kind.
Take my arm, Madame la Comtesse! The tumbril awaits. To the guillotine!
Wait till I get my badge, girls. I'll join you.
If you ever go East, brother, come out to my house for dinner. Nobody in St. Louis sets a better table than my dear wife, Agatha.
Jerry.
Yes, Doc?
Jerry, in the past I will admit, as one man to another, that economically I haven't been of much value to you. But... ...you don't suppose you could... ahem... put one on credit?
If talk was money, Doc, you'd be the best customer I got.
I'm leaving town, Jerry.
Honest?
Yes, my dear fellow, and I thought you might, in memory of our many happy...
All right, Doc, just this one.
Thank you, Jerry.
Here's a man goin' with you on the stagecoach, Doc. He's an Easterner from Kansas City, Missouri.
Kansas City, Kansas, brother.
Your health, Reverend!
I'm not a clergyman, my name is Peacock. I'm a... ahem...
He's a whiskey drummer.
What?
Well, well, how are you...
...Mr. Haycock!
Peacock!
You don't need to tell me, sir. A familiar name, an honoured name! I never forget a face of a friend. Samples?
Rye!
I need five dollars, Henry.
Why certainly, my dear, certainly. What is it this time, a new...?
I want to pay the butcher. Dinner will be at twelve o'clock. I've invited the Ladies of the Law and Order League.
Don't you worry, my dear, I'll be there.
All aboard for Dry Fork, Apache Wells, Lee Ferry and Lordsburg!
I'll take that, Dallas.
Oh, thanks.
In you go, Dallas, and a pleasant voyage.
Thank you, thank you, my friend.
I'll take it, Doctor.
Oh no, no, no trouble at all. I'll carry it on my lap.
Mrs. Whitney, you're not going to let your friend travel with that creature.
She's right, Lucy. Besides, you're not well enough to travel.
It's only a few hours, Nancy. I'm quite all right.
But you shouldn't travel a step without a doctor.
There is a doctor, dear. The driver told me.
Doctor? Doc Boone? Why, he couldn't doctor a horse!
Now, Lucy darling, you must be very careful, take good care of yourself -- oh, watch that step, now!
Now, ladies, both ride facing forward, please!
There we are!
Pleasant journey, Mrs. Mallory!
Why, thank you. Goodbye!
Goodbye!
Goodbye!
Like an angel in a jungle.
A very wild jungle.
What are you doing, Hatfield, talking to yourself?
You wouldn't understand, cowboy.
You've never seen an angel. Or a gentlewoman, [a thoroughbred].
Come on, ace bets.
I raise, gentlemen.
So long, Buck, so long, Curly. Nice trip, boys.
So long, boys, so long, kids.
Captain Sickels asks if you will deliver this despatch in Lordsburg the moment you arrive. The telegraph line has been cut.
Sure.

We're going with you as far as the noon station at Dry Fork. There's a troop of cavalry there. They'll take you on to Apache Wells. From Apache Wells you'll have another escort of soldiers into Lordsburg. You must warn your passengers that they travel at their own risk.
At their own risk? What's the trouble, Lieutenant?
Geronimo!
Geronimo! I... I ain't goin'.
Sit down!
Of course, the Army has no authority over you gentlemen. If you think it unsafe to make the trip...
This stage is going to Lordsburg. If you think it ain't safe to ride along with us, I figure we can get there without you soldier-boys.
I have orders, sir. I always obey orders.
Did you all hear what the Lieutenant said?
Yes, we heard.
Well, me and Buck are takin' this coach through, whether they's any passengers or not. Now whoever wants to get out can get out.
Courage, Reverend. Ladies first.
How 'bout you, Dallas?
What are you trying to do... scare somebody? They put me in here. Now let 'em try and put me out! There are worse things than Apaches.
If you take my advice, ma'am, you won't take this trip.
My husband is with his troops at Dry Fork. If there's danger I want to be with him.
Well, you see, brother, I have a wife and five children...
Then you're a man! By all the powers that be, Reverend, you're a man.
All right, folks.
Marshal...
Make room for one more!
I'm offering my protection to this lady.
I can shoot fairly straight if there's a need for it.
That's been proved too many times, Hatfield. All right, get in. We're late.
May I trouble you to move over, sir?...
Why, yes, of course.
Close the door.
Oh, Curly, we can't...
Get going, Buck.
Hey up! Bessie, Brownie, Bill!
Farewell, ladies.
Sweethearts!
Room for another passenger?
Sure, Mr. Gatewood. Goin' to Lordsburg?
That's right. Just got a telegram. Had to pack this bag and didn't have time to catch you at the Oriental.
Well... I've made it anyway.
Hi, Susy! Hi there, Billy! Gitty Ap! Git alang! Git alang, Susy!
Sure funny, Gatewood ketchin' us outside town that way.
I took this job ten years ago so's I could get enough money to marry my Mexican girl, Julietta. I been workin' hard at it ever since. Barney, git on there!
At marriage?
Why, certainly; my wife's got more relatives than you ever did see! I bet I'm feeding half the state of Chihuahua!
Don't it seem funny to you? About Gatewood?
home in Lordsburg? Nothing but frijole beans, that's all. Nothing but beans, beans, beans! Gitty ap, Sam!
Excuse me, ladies.
Warm today.
Your wife made it warm fer me today, Gatewood.
She was chairman of our farewell committee.
Fine-looking bunch of soldier-boys back there. It always gives me great pride in my country...
...when I see such fine young men in the U. S. Army. Anybody know where they're going?
Brother, aren't you aware of... ...what's happened?
I don't follow you, Reverend.
I'm not a clergyman...
My friend is a whiskey drummer. We're all going to be scalped, Gatewood. Massacred in one fell swoop.
That's why the soldiers are with us.
He's joking, of course.
Oh no, he's not. Oh dear no. I wish he were.
It's that old Apache butcher...
Geronimo.
Geronimo, that's the name of our butcher. He's jumped the reservation. He's on the warpath.
Geronimo? Well, why weren't the passengers notified? Why wasn't I told?
We were...
We were told, Gatewood.
Yes, yes.
Weren't you told when you got that message...
...from Lordsburg?
Oh yes, yes, yes, of course, of course, I forgot.
Now, doggone it, her grandfather's comin' up from Mexico to live with us!
I can't figure out how he got that message.
Who, my grandfather?
No, Gatewood.
Sweetheart!
Said he got a message.
Sweetheart!
The telegraph line ain't working.
Hey look, it's Ringo!
Yeah.
Hello, Kid.
Hiya, Curly. Hiya, Buck, how's your folks?
Fine... ...Fine, Ringo, except that my wife's grandfather...
Shut up!
Didn't expect you to be ridin' shotgun on this run, Marshal.
Goin' to Lordsburg?
I figured you'd be there by this time.
No, lame horse. Looks like you got another passenger.
Yeah.
I'll take the Winchester.
You might need me and this Winchester. I saw a coupla ranches burnin' last night.
I guess you don't understand, Kid. You're under arrest.
Curly...
Gimme that gun, Kid.
Everything all right, Marshal?
Everything's all right, Lieutenant.
Hope I ain't crowding you folks none.
Ain't Ringo a fine boy?
I think so.
Hey, you're just smarter'n a trade rat -- you knew all the time he was going to Lordsburg. Hey, reckon what he meant, he saw ranch-houses burnin'?
Apaches.
So you're the Ringo Kid.
My friends just call me Ringo. Nickname I had as a kid. My name's Henry.
Seems to me I knew your family, Henry.
Didin't I set your arm once when you were, oh... ...bucked off a horse?
You Doc Boone?
I certainly am.
Let's see, I'd just been honourably discharged from the Union Army after the War of the Rebellion.
You mean the war for the Southern Confederacy, suh.
I mean nothing of the kind, sir.
That was my kid brother broke his arm. You did a good job, Doc, even if you was drunk.
Thank you, son. Professional compliments are always pleasing.
Yes, they are.
What became of the boy whose arm I fixed?
He was murdered.
Put out that cigar.
You're annoying this lady.
Excuse me, madam.
Being so partial to the weed myself, I forget it disagrees with others.
A gentleman doesn't smoke in the presence of a lady.
Three weeks ago I took a bullet out of a man who was shot by a gentleman. The bullet was...
...in his back.
affronted Do you mean to insinuate...
Sit down, mister.
Doc don't mean any harm.
Be careful of ol' Bessie up there, now... Take it easy, hold it -- steady there, girl. Take a look, see if there ain't a stone in the hoof of that hoss down there.
Well, if it isn't my old friend, Sergeant Billy Pickett... How are you, Billy?
He's fine, Doc, and mighty glad to see you.
Great heavens to Betsie, we didn't figure on no stagecoach coming through with them Apaches raising Cain. I was just telling Billy there to hitch up the buckboard...
Now wait a minute -- you mean to say there are no troops at this station?
There ain't no soldiers here but what you see.
But my husband, Captain Mallory. I was told he was here.
He was, dearie. Got orders night afore last to join the soldiers at Apache Wells.
Well, that means we got to turn back.
I can't go back. See here, driver, this stage has started for Lordsburg and it's your duty to get us there.
And it's your duty, my boy, to come along with us.
It's my duty, Mr. Gatewood, to obey orders. I'm sorry.
If you soldiers go back, Lieutenant, we all gotta go back.
Captain Sickels ordered me to return from here immediately. I can't disobey orders.
I think we can get through all right, Curly.
Don't egg him on like that, Kid. I'm drivin' this outfit and if the soldiers are headin' back so am I.
I call this desertion of duty, young man. I'll take it up with your superior officers! I'll take it up with Washington if necessary.
That's your privilege, sir. But if you make any trouble here I'll put you under restraint.
Now don't lose your temper, don't lose your temper.
I'll tell you how we'll settle it. We'll take a vote. Inside, everybody.
Come on, Buck.
Oh, but Curly, I don't want to go...
Now, come on, girls, set yourselves down; I'll get you something to eat.
Now, folks, if we push on we can be in Apache Wells by sundown. Soldiers there will give us an escort as far as the ferry, and then it's only a hoot and a holler into Lordsburg.
We got four men can handle firearms... five with you, Ringo.
Doc can shoot, if sober.
I can shoot, I can shoot.
Now, Mrs. Mallory, I ain't goin' to put a lady in danger without she votes for it.
I've travelled all the way here from Virginia and I'm determined to get to my husband. I won't be separated any longer.
What's your vote, mister?
Well, I...
Where's your manners, Curly?
Ain't you going to ask the other lady first?
Well, what do you say?
What difference does it make? It doesn't matter.
I vote we go on.
I demand it, I'm standing on my legal rights.
What do you say, Hatfield?
Lordsburg.
Four.
You, Doc?
I am not only a philosopher, I am also a fatalist.
Somewhere, some time, there may be the right bullet or the wrong bottle waiting for Josiah Boone. Why worry when or where?
Yes or no?
Having this wisdom, sir, I have always courted danger. During the late war... when I had the honour, sir, to serve the Union...
...under our great President Abraham Lincoln...
...and General Phil Sheridan, I fought midst shot and shell and the cannons' roar...
Do you want to go back or not?
No!
I want another drink.
That's five.
Peacock.

I... I would like to go on, brother, I want to reach the bosom of my dear family in Kansas City, Kansas, as quick as possible... but I may never reach that bosom if we go on. Under the circumstances... I... you understand, go back with the bosoms... ...I mean with the soldiers.
One against! Well, Buck?
Buck says aye. That's six!
Nothin' gonna keep me out of Lordsburg, Curly.
There sure ain't. Well, folks, that settles it. We're goin' through. Buck, you get them horses changed. Set down, folks. Eat your grub.
But, Curly, ain't we gonna eat?
We'll eat later.
Here y'are, folks, food's on the table. Help yourselves, you got a long ride ahead of you.
You ain't drinking, Billy.
Set down here, ma'am.
Thank you.
May I find you another place, Mrs. Mallory? It's cooler by the window.
Thank you.
Looks like I got the plague, don't it.
No... it's not you.
Well, I guess you can't break out of prison and into society in the same week.
Please!... Please.
You're ill, Mrs. Mallory?
No... it's just... I'll be all right.
You're very kind... Why?
In the world I live in one doesn't often see a lady, Mrs. Mallory. [I'm only doing my duty as a Southern gentleman.]
Have you ever been in Virginia?
I was in your father's regiment.
I should remember your name. You're Mr... Hatfield?
That's what I'm called, yes.
Why do you look at me like that?
All aboard for Apache Wells, East Ferry...
The horses are changed... we'd better get going.
...and Lordsburg.
Okay, Ringo, get going. Mrs. Pickett, tell Billy the buckboard's all ready. Let's get going.
Have a pleasant journey, Mrs. Mallory, and my compliments to your husband.
What'd you say?
Nothin'.
Oh, excuse me. Well, why don't you say somethin'? A man gets nervous settin' here like a mummy, thinkin' about Indians!
You say somethin'. You been talkin' all day without makin' any sense.
All right, here's somethin' that makes sense! If I was you I'd let 'em shoot it out!
Let who?
Luke Plummer and the Kid. They'd be a lot more peace on the frontier if Luke Plummer was too full o' lead to hold his liquor.

I ain't sayin' I don't share your sentiments, Buck, but you're a born fool. First place Luke would kill the Kid in a gun-fight. Second place if Luke did get shot he's got two brothers jest as ornery as he is, and if Ike Plummer didn't kill the Kid then Hank Plummer would. Nope, safest place for Ringo is in the pen and I aim to get him there all in one piece. Time he gets out Luke Plummer will of picked a fight with the wrong man and it'll all blow over.
Well, I'll be doggoned! I done you an injury, Curly. I thought you was after the reward.
Reward! Why, the Kid's old man and me was friends. Besides, I can use that five hundred in gold.
I can't get over the impertinence of that young lieutenant! I'll make it warm for that shavetail!
I'll report him to Washington! We pay taxes to the government and what do we get? Not even protection from the Army!
I don't know what the government's coming to! Instead of protecting businessmen, it's poking its nose into business.
Why, they're talking now about having bank examiners... ...as if we didn't know how to run our own banks.
I actually had a letter, from some popinjay official, saying they were going to inspect my books! I have a programme, gentlemen, that should be blazoned on every newspaper in the country.
America for Americans! Don't let the government meddle with business! Reduce taxes! Our national debt is shocking...
...over a billion dollars! What the country needs is a businessman for President!
What the country needs is more bottle.
What?
Bottle!
You're drunk, sir.
I'm happy, Gatewood. Woof!
How come you're using this road? It's gonna be cold up there.
I'm using my head. Those beach-crowd Apaches don't like snow.
Wouldn't you like me to sit beside you? You could lean on my shoulder. You look so tired.
No, thank you.
How are you feeling, Mrs. Mallory?
Is there any water?
Driver! Canteen, please!
Just a minute, Mrs. Mallory.
Haven't I seen this crest before? Isn't this from Ringfield Manor?
I wouldn't know, Mrs. Mallory. I won that cup on a wager.
How about the other lady?
Thanks.
Sorry -- no silver cups.
This is fine!
No!
Please...
Howdy, Chris. Seven hours from Dry Fork. That's fast driving, amigo!
Get the folks a bite to eat, Chris, while we change horses. We're pushin' right on to Lordsburg.
You come without soldiers?
Sure, we wasn't scared. Never seen an Apache, did we, Curly?
Where's the cavalry, Chris?
Yeah, where is the soldiers?
Ain't no soldiers.
Huh?
Soldiers gone.
Where's Captain Mallory? Where's my husband? Where is he?
You his wife... I think?
Yes, where is he? Did he go with his men?
Si, señora. Leetle... what you call it... skirmish...
...with Apaches last night. Soldiers take Captain Mallory to Lordsburg...
...I think. He get... hurt, maybe.
Badly?
...Yes, señora. I think so.
Mrs. Mallory, I'm awfully sorry. If there's anything I can...
I'm all right. Thank you.
Marshal! Come here. Quickly!
Come on, Doc.
Let's go, Doc.
A sick woman on our hands!
That's all we needed!
I... I feel kinda sick myself.
We're in a fine fix, my friends. It's a fine country we're living in. The Army has no right to leave a public place like this undefended!
Looks to me like the Army's got its hands pretty full, mister.
Have you a wife?
Si, señora.
Call her.
Go into the kitchen and get some hot water -- lots of hot water.
Yes, ma'am.
A fine member of the medical profession!
Drunken beast!
Coffee... gimme coffee... black coffee... lots of it...
That makes four, Doc.
More, and blacker!
Ain't that enough? You'll have it coming out of your ears in a minute!
Keep'er comin', Curly!
Drink it down.
It'll make you feel better.
All right, now!
Isn't that drunken swine sober yet?
We're doing the best we can!
Well, hurry!
That's it! Again!
Sit down here, Doc.
Keep the fire going, Chris! Plenty of water!
Savages!
That's my wife...
Yakima.
But she... she's a savage.
Si, señor, she's leetle bit savage... I think.
There's something about this. That girl's an Apache!
Yeah.
Sure, she's one of Geronimo's people... I think. Maybe not so bad to have Apache wife. Apaches don't bother me... I think.
All right, Doc?
All right.
All right, now listen.
It's them vaqueros! They've run away!
Yeah! With the spare horses.
Them coyotes gimme the creeps. They sound jest like... ...jest like a baby.
Black eight!
It's a baby!
It's a little girl.
It's a little girl. Well I'll be doggoned!
Why didn't somebody tell me?
How is Mrs. Mallory?
She's going to be all right.
Well I'll be doggoned. Did you know?
Well, I'll be doggoned!
Don't do that.
Doctor Boone!
Come on, boys, three cheers for old Doc Boone! Hip, hip...
Sssssh! Quiet!
Well, we ought to be...
Quiet! Mrs. Mallory.
Kid, I know why you go to Lordsburg, Kid. I like you. I knew your poppa. He was a good friend of mine. If you know who's in Lordsburg you stay away... I think.
You mean Luke Plummer?
Luke... Ike... Hank... all there together. I saw them.
You sure of that, Chris?
Sure I can tell you the truth.
Thanks, Chris. That's all I wanted to know.
You crazy if you go... I think. You stay away, Kid. Three against one no good.
You oughtn't go too far, Miss Dallas.
Apaches like to sneak up and pick off strays.
You visiting in Lordsburg?
No, I... I have friends there. And maybe I can find work.
Why don't you escape, Kid? Why don't you escape?
I aim to, Miss Dallas... in Lordsburg.
Why Lordsburg? Why don't you make for the Border now?
My father and brother was shot down by the Plummers. I guess you don't know how it feels to lose your own folks like that.
I lost mine when I was a kid. There was a massacre in the Superstition Mountains.
That's tough, especially on a girl. [It's a hard country.]
You have to live, no matter what happens.
Yeah, that's it.
Look, Miss Dallas...
...you got no folks... neither have I. Maybe I'm taking a lot for granted... but I watched you with that baby... that other woman's baby... and you looked... ...well...
...but... well... I still got a ranch across the Border. It's a nice place... a real nice place... trees... grass... water... a cabin half- built...
...a man could live there... and a woman.
Will you go?
You don't know me! You don't know who I am!
I know all I want to know. You're... the kind of girl a man wants to marry.
Oh, don't talk like that!
What you doin' out here, Kid?
Stick close to the reservation.
Curly!
What's wrong, Chris?
My wife, Yakima. She run away.
When I wake up she's... ...gone.
'Scuse me, Kid.
The way you come bustin' in here you'd think... we was bein' attacked. You can find another wife, Chris.
Sure I find another wife. But she take my rifle and my horse! I never sell her, I love her so much.
I beat her with the whip and she never get tired!
Your wife?
My horse! Find wife easy, yes, but not horse like that!
Mala Yakima!
I knew that woman was a thief.
What's the matter with you, Gatewood?
My valise! Where's my valise?
Which one of you has got it?
Here. I been usin' it for a pillow. Thought you wouldn't mind.
Didn't I tell you to keep your hands off my things?
Well, I'm sorry I...
That squaw of yours will find some Apaches and bring 'em back here.
My wife's people they won't bother me... I think.
They bother me... I think!
Chris... is this bar open?
Sure, all the time, señor, si.
What are we wasting time for? Let's make a break for it.
We got a delicate woman to consider.
Well, do you want her to stay here and be butchered, with the rest of us?
Why don't you think of anyone else for once?
Are you insinuating...?
Easy, easy, easy! Quiet, boys, quiet. We ain't butchered yet. But you're right...
...we'd better get goin' for Lordsburg soon as we can.
Might be a good idea, Curly, if -- uh...
...if Doc took a look at the patient.
Yeah, and Little Coyote.
If you'll join me, Doctor...
No thanks.
Good morning.
You're looking chipper today.
You're up early, Dallas.
She didn't go to bed, Doctor.
I'm afraid she sat up all night, while I slept.
Oh, I slept in the chair a lot.
Well, it was nice to stay awake and hold the baby.
We've got to get you to Lordsburg, Little Coyote. That's what the boys christened her last night from the way she squalled.
Little Coyote. How do you feel?
Fine, Doctor. A bit tired.
Doctor, do you think my husband...
Never mind. The best medicine he can have is to see you two safe and sound. You make up your mind to get there.
I have, Doctor.
That's the talk. You need more strength. Rest all you can. Dallas, maybe you can fix up some broth.
She has already.
Good! How about some coffee for the boys?
Try and sleep for a while, little lady. And don't look so proud. I've brought hundreds of 'em into the world... ...once upon a time, and each new one is always the prettiest.
Doc...
...Ringo asked me to marry him.
Is it wrong, for a girl like me? If a man and woman are in love, it's all right, ain't it, Doc?
You're going to get hurt, child, worse than you've ever been hurt. Don't you know that boy's headed back to prison? Besides, if you two go into Lordsburg...
...together, he's going to find out all about you.
He's not going to Lordsburg. All I want is for you to tell me it's all right.
Who am I to tell you what's right or wrong, child? All right, go ahead.
Do it, if you can. Good luck.
Thanks, Doc.
Ringo...
Well, Doc?
